 Abstract This paper develops an analytical framework to examine the Brazilian economy. A macro economic projection model is developed based on a consis- tency framework for 1980. After 1980 the Brazil economy began to show many serious weaknesses, unemployment rose rapidly, the current account deteriorated, and the external debt rose to over US$90 billion by 1983. The projections suggest that even relatively strong growth rates of around 6 percent per annm although large enough to support the absorption of increases in the labor force will not be sufficient to reduce the pool of unemployed that has accumulated during the recession. It seems that the development strategy or the sixties and seventies and the concomitant technology is no longer adequate. On the external side the recent performance in the merchandise balance by Brazil has been quite strong but it is essential to maintain this highly favorable balance ir the current account, and the debt servicing required is to remain within accept- able limits. This in turn implies that Import expansion should be strongly conditioned by a favorable export performance. The multi-sectoral nature of the model provides considerable insight into analyzing which sectors may be most appropriate for various initiatives and where one may expect unfavorable consequences. A viable policy package to lower unemployment, maintain domestic balance and curb debt accumulation will require a careful blending of policies. The paper indicates which policy instruments may be appropriate for various goals but the choice and blend will in the end be a polltical decision.

 II. Recent Macroeconodic DevelopEents 2.1 The "Brazil Model" In tne nineteen sixties and seventies, the Brazilan economy achieved one of the highest growth rates in the world. The annual growth rate of GNP on a per capita basis averaged close to 5 percent during this period. There is an extensive literature on the 'Brazil model' for development, not only on its impact on various groups in the Brazil experience, but also on whether either the whole approach or part of it night be suitable for other developing countries. There is some debate on the extent to which the initial surge in growth in the early sixties may be attributed to an enlightened policy regime or simply the successful utilization of the excess capacity available at the beginning of the decade. In any case by the late sixties and thereafter, very large investments were required to sustain the growth, particularly in infra- structure, power, transportation. A complex array of state and parastatal organizations evolved to carry out this work. t/ Much of the financing for these projects was facilitated by the availability of relatively cheap (in real terms) foreign money. Up to the early seventies external balance was achieved by a judicious mixture of incentives for export promotion together with protective measures to stimulate domestic industry. I/ For exaomle MNDES devoted most of its resources to infrastructure and heavy industry. Knight et al. (1983) estimate that in 1978 BNDES accounted for -40 percent of gross fized capital formation in the industrial sector.

In the 1960s the import substitution strategy in a number of sectors resulted in merchadise exports being dominated by agricultural goods.  - 61 - VII. Summary and Conclusions Policy based lending has assumed an Increasing role in development lending in recent years. The framworks available for the evaluation or policy prescriptions vary from basic one-gap approaches, with little room for distinguishing differential policy effects, to fully endogenous equilibrium system. The latter approach typically requires a few man-years of effort and even then it is difficult to incorporate into projection analysis. The approach taken in this study lies between these two poles in that it develops a methodology that can be adapted to most country situations with less than a man-year of effort. At the same time, the framework presented in this paper and the ensuing outcome analyses provide a systematic linkage between available economic policy options and their macroeoonomic effects at a relatively detailed level. This paper is specifically addressed to the current economic situation is Brazil, but may be readily adapted for other countries. In order to capture the effects of policy measures, the framework was designed with five basic facets of the analytical context in mind: productive structure, institutional structure, fir.ancial structure, external debt and trade structure, and employment. Thw .uctive structure was designed to capture differential characteristi( 4th respect to import oontent, export concentration, consumption, phb -cal capital intensity and employment. Prices reflect costs for iaports, internediaoe and domestic factors. The institutional structure (here, private, federal enterprises, and *other govern entu) was chosen, in part, because of differences- n consumption,
 - 62 - patterns and available investment alternatives. More importantly, these distinctions were made to reflect distinctions in policy alternatives and effects. Thus, for example, this structure allows for the identification of effects of changes in direct and indirect taxation as well as transfer and subsidy schema and sectoral investment choices. The separation of federal enterprises and "other goverrmentt is particularly useful as much of the current policy debate centers on the role of the public sector. This methodologY allows for estimation of the contribution of federal enterprises to current, capital and financial accounts under alternate policy scenarios. The grounds for the inclusion of a comprehensive external debt and trade structure are obvious. It is clear that, because of the importance of the external debt and trade in determining requirements and hence constraints for the the domestic system, the framework must be capable of reflecting changes in the type, structure and terms of the debt. It must also be refined enough to capture the effects of changes in the external environment on trade markets, and hence, the behavior of the domestic economy. Various resched- ulirg or restructuring schemes for both guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt can be investigated. The integration of a financial structure adds a new qualitative dimension to the analytic framework. The financial structure provides the linkage between the patterns and levels of physical activity in the system and the financial balances of the institutional actors. Since this linkage takes place In nominal terms, the financial balances provide the foundation for the analysis of accommodating financial flows. The identification of the sources of these accommodating flows provides a nexus for the analysis of policy outcomes in a nominal-monetary framework.
 - 63 - The structure is rounded out by the addition of the employment framework, which serves to provide information on constraining conditions in that area. Taken together, these features provide a general framework for evaluating the effects of exogenous forces on the economic function of a system and simultaneously evaluating the effects of policy options in such circumstances. The methodology is quite robust so that more detailed modules may be readily incorporated. Similarly, as better data becomes available, such as more up-to-date export price forecasts, they can be introduced without undue difficulty. The exogenous forcea and policy considerations are of both a short- term and a long-term nature. Thus it is possible to look at the choices necessitated by short term effects of interest rate and external price changes. On the other hand, the long term development issues raised by these short term effects and policy responses to them show up clearly in the evolution of the productive structure and concomitant employment dynamics. This paper has examined the problems and choices facing the Brazilian economy in the context of a frarmework having the aforementioned features. The analysis has raised a number of issues as a focus for concentration in the continuing design and evolution of development policy choices for that economy. In addition to the specific problems and choices which Brazil faces, this study provides an example of an analytic approach to the assessment of the economic envirornment with respect to policy choices which might be carried out for other economies. It exhibits- the benefits of a linked, -consistent, focal framework in understanding systemic affects of particular policy choices and/or combinations of such policies. It also exhibits the importance of a

doc.abstracts: This paper develops an analytical framework to examine the Brazilian economy. A macro economic projection model is developed based on a consistency framework for 1980. After 1980, the economy began to show many serious weaknesses, unemployment rose rapidly, the current account deteriorated, & the external debt rose to over US$90 billion by 1983. The projections suggest that even relatively strong growth rates of around 6% per annum, although large enough to support the absorption of increases in the labor force, will not be sufficient to reduce the pool of unemployed that has accumulated during the recession. The recent performance in the merchandise balance of Brazil has been quite strong but it is essential to maintain this highly favourable balance if the current account, & the debt servicing required is to remain within acceptable limits. This implies that import expansion should be strongly conditioned by a favourable export performance. The multi-sectoral nature of the model provides considerable insight into analyzing which sectors may be most appropriate for various initiatives & where one may expect unfavourable consequences. The paper indicates which policy instruments may be appropriate for various goals but the choice & blend will in the end be a political decision.
